title: The playground of Russia’s royalty
text:
IT IS like the Hunger Games of the animal world. Tourists at this park pay extra to select a sheep, cow or chicken from a menu and watch it fed live to the tigers. Warning: Distressing content. World Travel Viking’s Ingvar plies 1100km in Russia known as the Waterways of the Tsars by: What are these? The sun rises over the Neva in St Petersburg. Picture: Getty Source: Getty Images 
TWENTY minutes from the heart of Moscow, longship Viking Ingvar is at rest in the Moscow Canal gently nudging the dock at North Port when the party begins. 
In the Panorama Bar, the clinking of glasses of cocktails and premium wines is well under way when Jochen Kunkel takes the microphone. 
“Good evening,” the stout German maitre d’hotel from Cologne bellows cheerily at 200 guests assembled for their first night aboard. “I just want to tell you about dinner and let you know our executive chef Joachim Meier has outdone himself tonight,” he said. 
“We have lollo rosso salad and shaved serrano ham with raspberry dressing and it’s very yummy,” he effuses. “We have beef stroganoff with herbed noodles, beets, salted cucumbers and smetana, and that’s very, very yummy. 
“And, we also have bittersweet chocolate pots de creme and, I have to tell you, that that is extremely yummy,” he grins. “See you there.” 
“There” is the ship’s Neva Restaurant, a temple of fine dining for which Viking Cruises’ fleet of three longboats has become famous since the company launched their Russian river cruises in 1997. 
Ingvar accommodates 210 guests in 104 staterooms and suites spread around three decks, all with private verandas, full-length sliding doors, river views, hotel-style beds with quality linens, flat-screen TVs, private bathrooms with L’Occitane toiletries, telephones, safes, refrigerators and free Wi-Fi. The Church of St Dmitry on Blood can be seen in Uglich, one of the towns that’s part of the “Golden Ring”. Picture: Getty Source: Getty Images 
Ingvar ’s layout reflects the minimalism, comfort and functionality of traditional Scandinavian design. There’s a sun deck with a shaded sitting area, an open-air promenade deck, elevator, observation lounge, two bar-lounges with vista windows and Neva Restaurant with panoramic views, open seating, fine wines, a choice of buffet or a la carte and elaborate five-course dinners. 
Between May and October, the triple-deck riverboats ply continuously between Moscow and St Petersburg along an 1100km system of scenic rivers, lakes, canals, locks and reservoirs known as the Waterways of the Tsars. 
The 13-day itineraries include four days exploring each city and five days cruising an arc of some of Russia’s oldest towns – dubbed the Golden Ring. 
Guests are generally English speaking, well-travelled professionals in the 55-plus range. With a destination-focused itinerary, Viking has skilfully combined a casual and convivial shipboard atmosphere with a detailed immersion into Russia’s history, arts, culture, politics, language and cuisine – with guides conducting on-board lectures and visits ashore. 
In Moscow, tours include the Metro underground, St Basil’s Cathedral, galleries, museums, Red Square, GUM department store and the Kremlin. Port excursions from Moscow include a visit to the 19th century GUM department store on Red Square. Picture: David May Source: Supplied 
After four days exploring Moscow, Ingvar slips silently from the dock and idles up the 130km Moscow Canal. 
After a lesson in elementary Russian, it’s cocktail hour in the Panorama Bar with soothing music by resident pianist Edouardo and songstress, Marisa. 
Where the Moscow Canal enters the Volga River, anglers are fishing from dinghies and off riverbanks covered by meadows and forests. 
First stop is Uglich, which dates from 1148, full of cottages and onion-domed churches including the Church of St Dmitry on the Blood, infamous as the site where Ivan the Terrible’s son Dmitry was murdered in 1591. 
Yaroslavl is the next Volga city founded in 1010 where the period’s best artists covered the walls and ceilings of the 17th century Church of St Elijah the Prophet with some of Russia’s finest icons and frescoes. 
The historical centre was added to the UNESCO World Heritage List in 2005 and is full of antique shops, boutiques, cafes and a covered market selling seafood, caviar, local produce and forest honeys. 
The landscape changes. Silver birch forests, cherry orchards, dairy farms and summer dachas (cottages) slip past before Ingvar enters the scenic Sheksna River. 
In the Panorama Bar, tour guide Sasha delivers a talk on Russian politics before a cooking class where chef Joachim Meier demonstrates how to prepare Siberian pelmeni (dumplings). Viking Ingvar executive chef Joachim Meier demonstrates how to make Siberian pelmeni (dumplings). Picture: David May Source: Supplied 
Following the 6pm cocktail hour and dinner in the Neva, maitre d’ Jochen Kunkel explains the complex characteristics of vodka, with the appropriate tastings, as Ingvar enters Lake Onega. 
This serene lake, Europe’s second largest, is peppered with 1650 islands, few more beautiful than the wild, isolated Kizhi where centuries-old traditional timber buildings from around the region have been saved, transported and reassembled. 
They include the 22-domed, all-timber Transfiguration Church, crafted without nails, and a farmhouse where scenes from the 2012 movie Anna Karenina were filmed. All are UNESCO World Heritage listed. 
From Lake Onega, the Svir River connects with the Neva River flowing west to St Petersburg, arguably Russia’s most beautiful city with a wealth of architectural and artistic treasures, especially the extraordinarily ornate Church of Our Saviour on Spilled Blood. 
A playground of Russian royalty, St Petersburg has an astonishing collection of fabulous palaces where tsars and empresses lived in gilt grandeur including the State Hermitage, Catherine Palace and Ingvar ’s final shore excursion, the confections of Peterhof Palace. The extraordinary Church of Our Saviour on Spilled Blood in St Petersburg. Picture: David May Source: Supplied 
It’s the last night aboard Ingvar and the party continues with cocktail hour on the Sun Deck, French wines in the Neva and the sounds of Edouardo and Marisa ending the voyage with another flawless day of culture and casual conviviality. 

The writer was a guest of Viking Cruises. 

RUSSIA 
GETTING THERE 
Viking Ingvar 13-day Waterways of the Tsars cruises run both ways between Moscow and St Petersburg, start from $7395 a person twin share and include river-view deluxe stateroom, 11 guided tours with four UNESCO World Heritage sites, all meals, complimentary Silver Spirits (premium) beverage package, unlimited wines, beers, premium cocktails, soft drinks, juices, specialty coffees, port charges, gratuities and free Wi-Fi. Conditions apply. 
VISAS 
See russianembassy-au.ru/en/visa-consular-affairs/tourist-visa.html 
SPENDING 
A$1 buys about 40 roubles generally exchangeable at most Australian and other international airports. There is no exchange facility on-board.
